qa_pairs.question: What was your occupation before retirement?
qa_pairs.answer: I was a City plumber, a retired City plumber who worked for DPW.
qa_pairs.source_text: my occupation was City plumber Im a retired City plumber worked for DPW

qa_pairs.question: Where were you born and what was your early life like?
qa_pairs.answer: I was born in Fort Knox, Kentucky, and I'm an army brat, so I'm from all over.
qa_pairs.source_text: I was born in Kentucky Fort Knox Kentucky and Im an army brat so Im from all over

qa_pairs.question: When did you move to San Francisco and where did you first live?
qa_pairs.answer: We came to San Francisco in 1964. We first moved to Glen Park for about six months and then got quarters on the Presidio in the Waring housing area.
qa_pairs.source_text: we came to San Francisco in 64. and we moved first to Glen Park for like six months and then we got um quarters on the Presidio in wearing housing area

qa_pairs.question: What was the housing situation like in the Presidio?
qa_pairs.answer: The Waring housing area provided housing for military folks, and it basically cost what your stipend was from the military.
qa_pairs.source_text: wearing housing area was provided provided housing for military folks and it didnt cost me it it basically costs what your stipend was what the military gave you

qa_pairs.question: Why did your family move back to San Francisco from Oakland in 1967?
qa_pairs.answer: We moved back because there were riots in Oakland in 1967, and we couldn't stand it.
qa_pairs.source_text: we went over to Oakland for six months and couldnt stand it because they were trying to burn the city down um is in 67 they were riding over there and then we got we came back to San Francisco

qa_pairs.question: What was your neighborhood like when you lived on Parsons Street?
qa_pairs.answer: It was a rich hippie area with neighbors like Country Joe and the Fish, Jefferson Starship, and Jules Brassard.
qa_pairs.source_text: I lived on Parsons Street Parson street right above the hate 67th I think was 66 at the end of 67-68 so we had as our neighbors Country Joe and the Fish on Jefferson Starship Jew or star airplane Jefferson or airplane it back then and we had Jules brassard practicing his his saxophone across the street and it was basically a rich hippie area

qa_pairs.question: What challenges did your parents face when looking for housing in San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: When my parents first went looking for housing, they were told that Green and Kaufman didn't sell to black people in the Richmond, even if they had the money.
qa_pairs.source_text: when my parents first went looking for housing in the city um they went to green and Kaufman on yerry street and they were told that they didnt not that green and Kaufman I dont I dont think it was the statement that green and Kaufman didnt sell to black people but theyre saying that if you want to buy in the Richmond they didnt sell to black people

qa_pairs.question: How did your parents manage to buy property in San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: They bought three flats divided into five units on Hay Street and later bought another house. They were smart enough to have renters pay for their building.
qa_pairs.source_text: my parents um you know theyre they were smart enough to know that you know theyd have the renters pay for their building so they bought they bought three Flats they it was three Flats divided up into five units and thats where we moved on Hay Street and then two years later they bought another house

qa_pairs.question: What was the housing market like for working-class people in the past?
qa_pairs.answer: It was not unusual for working people to buy things in the city. A plumber could buy a home, a vacation home in Clear Lake, and another in Bodega.
qa_pairs.source_text: that was not unusual that working people could buy things in the city then I have friends that lived in public housing the father became a plumber he bought a home he bought a vacation home and in Clear Lake he bought a vacation home in Bodega

qa_pairs.question: How has the affordability of housing in San Francisco changed over time?
qa_pairs.answer: It used to be affordable, but now I wouldn't be able to live here without the building my mother left me. I would probably live in a studio paying $1,800 or more.
qa_pairs.source_text: my current housing situation Im living in a building my mother left to me I actually left me to live in and left to my kids and so if you didnt have that how difficult would it be to live in San Francisco I wouldnt be living here I wouldnt be able to afford it I probably live in a in a studio or something you know uh 400 square foot Studio or something and Id probably be paying eighteen hundred dollars or fifteen hundred dollars or more than that

qa_pairs.question: What impact did development have on San Francisco's housing market?
qa_pairs.answer: Development commodified housing, forcing people out and making it unaffordable. It used to be a city full of union jobs where everyone could make a decent living.
qa_pairs.source_text: when development started in the city it moved everybody out they commodified housing they wanted to get the last Penny they could out of a out of real estate and that forced everybody to move

qa_pairs.question: What are your views on current housing policies in San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: The city should make policies that cater to working people, not investors. Housing should be homes, not just secured investments.
qa_pairs.source_text: I think you have to make a commitment to the people that work here that run the city I mean not necessarily run the city but they do labor here that you provide housing form and you have to make policies that attract better cater to working people not to investors
